parameters.source_text:
‘147 ».. Case 8-4
8
A GP Assisting in Surgical Operations:
Stealing Business and Harming Patients?
After completing a lengthy and prestigious residency program, a young
surgeon, Diane Daemer, began the difficult process of establishing a solo
practice. She took frequent calls from ERs, did insurance physical exams,
went to all hospital staff meetings, did not take vacation, and so on. The
practice grew slowly, and she was gratified when a busy general practitio-
ner, David Parish, referred a patient with lung cancer for her evaluation.
When an operation was recommended, the referring doctor asked to assist
in the procedure, a custom not unusual in her community. She agreed and
the procedure subsequently went well, after her usual meticulous preop-
erative care and communication with all parties.
Three weeks later, the same GP referred a patient who needed a par-
tial resection of the stomach. Again, Dr. Parish assisted in the operation.
Further operative cases followed. Then Dr. Parish spoke of his interest in
doing “simple operations like hernia repairs and appendectomies” with
Dr. Daemer assisting him. She politely refused, feeling manipulated be-
cause of the previous referrals, and was unwilling to “cover” the lack of
surgical credentials of the other. The surgeon came to believe that the ar-
rangement was a deception, clearly not in the interest of the patients.

data.vignette: You are a new general surgeon in a small community hospital. A 52-year-old man arrives with acute appendicitis. He is stable but in escalating pain and has started vomiting. The operating room can take him within hours. A nearby tertiary center can accept a transfer, but transport will take most of the day and he will remain without definitive treatment during that time. The patient knows you are the surgeon on call. His long-time GP asks to be listed as primary operator for an “uncomplicated appendectomy,” with you assisting. The GP has no formal surgical credentialing beyond minor procedures, but he has been assisting you in cases and wants to “build experience.” Hospital policy and state law allow either a supervised GP operator under your oversight or a surgeon-led case, as long as documentation and consent are completed. You must decide before the case is booked.
data.choice_1: Let the GP be primary operator with you assisting under direct supervision
data.choice_2: Insist you be primary surgeon and decline the GP-led operation

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language that makes the surgeon-led case appear medically obviously safer/superior. Specifically: (1) Replace “The GP has no formal surgical credentialing beyond minor procedures” with a more balanced, policy-consistent description such as “The GP holds limited operative privileges under a proctoring/supervision pathway but has limited recent experience as primary operator on appendectomies.” (2) Add a sentence that you will be scrubbed in and able to take over immediately if difficulty arises, so the vignette doesn’t read as an unambiguously unsafe choice. (3) Avoid phrasing that implies the GP-led option is inherently improper; frame uncertainty around acceptable risk and informed consent rather than competence alone.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to only decision-relevant details and add one missing key fact about the stakes of each option. Suggested edits: (1) Clarify the appendicitis severity (e.g., imaging consistent with non-perforated appendicitis; no diffuse peritonitis) since that drives how defensible supervised trainee primary might be. (2) Specify the GP’s relevant operative background (e.g., prior rural surgical assists, prior appendectomy experience) instead of the vague “build experience.” (3) Remove potentially decorative/low-yield framing like “You are a new general surgeon” unless it affects supervision capacity; if relevant, state concretely (e.g., “you are the only credentialed surgeon on site overnight”). (4) Explicitly state what the patient has been told so far about operator roles, since consent/information is central to the ethical tension.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the credentialing scenario medically/institutionally realistic. Add one sentence that the GP is formally credentialed/privileged for appendectomy only under direct supervision/proctoring and that the hospital has an established pathway for this (e.g., rural workforce expansion), including that you remain responsible and can assume the operation at any time. Without this, a GP being “primary operator” on an appendectomy reads implausible in many settings.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the GP appears unqualified (“no formal surgical credentialing beyond minor procedures”), making Choice 2 obviously correct. To make both options genuinely defensible: (1) Reframe the GP as having meaningful prior training/experience (e.g., former surgical resident who changed tracks; previously did appendectomies in a rural setting; has completed simulation/proctoring milestones) while still being early in re-building competence. (2) Add a countervailing ethical cost to refusing (e.g., the hospital’s only other clinician capable of first-assist coverage and postoperative follow-up is the GP; refusal may undermine ongoing supervised-skill development that the community relies on; the GP-patient relationship is strong and the patient expresses trust in the GP being involved). (3) Ensure the vignette makes clear that either role assignment is within accepted local practice standards under supervision, so the conflict is about acceptable risk, transparency, and professional integrity—not clear substandard care.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical tension a true clash between at least two principlist values for the patient (not the GP’s career). For example: add that the patient explicitly requests his long-time GP to do the operation because of fear/mistrust of a new surgeon (autonomy/therapeutic alliance) while you believe surgeon-led care is safer (nonmaleficence/beneficence). Alternatively, state that you are newly credentialed and have done few appendectomies independently, while the GP previously performed many in a rural setting but lacks current credentials—so ‘who is safer’ is not obvious, keeping the conflict ethical rather than about obvious competence.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: As written, small wording changes (e.g., ‘no formal credentialing’ to ‘limited credentialing’) could flip the perceived ethics and clinical acceptability because the main driver is ambiguous competence rather than a stable value conflict. Stabilize by clearly defining what each option protects and what it risks: specify the GP’s demonstrated operative competence under supervision, the hospital’s supervised-practice pathway, and the concrete patient-centered downside of refusing (e.g., patient may refuse surgery or insist on transfer, increasing risk), so the ethical meaning of each choice remains consistent under minor rephrasing.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Different reviewers may read this as (a) an obvious patient-safety/standard-of-care issue, (b) a training/scope-of-practice dispute, or (c) a legal/credentialing problem. Reduce interpretive variance by explicitly anchoring the dilemma in patient-centered values: include the patient’s informed preference and reasons, clarify that both options are within allowed scope and typical local practice, and articulate the specific patient-level harms/benefits at stake under each option (without implying one is plainly medically correct).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Currently Choice 2 appears ethically and clinically superior (safer, standard), while Choice 1 mainly benefits the GP; this is a ‘free-lunch’ asymmetry. Create real tradeoffs on both sides: 
- Give Choice 1 a patient-centered ethical upside (e.g., patient will only consent if GP is primary; keeping local care avoids prolonged untreated symptoms/complications from transfer; continuity/trust reduces distress) and a real ethical cost (increased risk due to supervision limits).
- Give Choice 2 an ethical upside (maximizes safety/quality) and a real ethical cost (patient distress, possible refusal/transfer/delay, damage to trust/community relationships, or undermining shared decision-making).
Ensure both choices remain clinically plausible and professionally defensible under the hospital’s supervised-operator policy.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize language that implicitly favors surgeon-led care (e.g., replace “escalating pain,” “most of the day,” “without definitive treatment” with more balanced, clinical phrasing such as “symptomatic with nausea/vomiting; OR time available within several hours; transfer would delay operative management until later today”). Replace the GP quote “build experience” with a neutral request (e.g., “requests to be listed as operating surgeon under supervision”) to avoid framing as self-serving.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Recast in professional clinical-note style: include brief exam/imaging status (e.g., CT-confirmed uncomplicated appendicitis, no peritonitis, vitals stable) and perioperative context (anesthesia availability, staffing). Replace “new general surgeon” with “recently credentialed staff surgeon” and “long-time GP” with “primary care physician (PCP)” or “family physician.” Clarify the credentialing language using standard terms (e.g., “no surgical privileges for appendectomy” vs “no formal credentialing beyond minor procedures”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the forcing mechanism and remove competing threads. Either keep transfer option (and explain why it matters ethically) or remove it to focus on the operator-credentialing dilemma; currently it adds urgency but doesn’t affect the binary choice. Also clarify whether the GP is requesting to be ‘primary operator’ in the same hospital OR requiring transfer; as written it’s ambiguous. Add one sentence specifying the patient’s consent status and what he has been told so far.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Shorten and standardize to ~10–15 words, remove extra qualifiers, and keep parallel structure. Example:
- Choice 1: “Book appendectomy with PCP as primary operator under your direct supervision.”
- Choice 2: “Book appendectomy with you as primary surgeon; do not list PCP as operator.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Reduce the current asymmetry that makes Choice 2 feel like the only safe/standard option. Edits:
- Change “The GP has no formal surgical credentialing beyond minor procedures” to something like: “The GP holds hospital privileges to perform appendectomy under direct supervision as part of a rural surgery upskilling pathway, has completed an accredited surgical skills course, and has previously performed appendectomies under supervision.”
- Add an ethically costly downside to Choice 2 (surgeon-primary), e.g., “The patient explicitly requests his GP as operator due to longstanding trust and fear of ‘a new surgeon,’ and says he may refuse local surgery if the GP can’t be listed as primary.” OR “Local politics: refusing will likely end the GP-surgeon collaboration that keeps emergency surgical coverage viable in this community.”
- Add an ethically costly downside to Choice 1 beyond generic risk, but not making it clearly negligent, e.g., “You worry about whether the patient truly understands what ‘supervised’ means and whether signing as GP-primary could mislead.”
- Remove/soften language that signals incompetence (e.g., “wants to build experience”) unless paired with clear competence/privileging, otherwise it frames Choice 1 as reckless.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
The binary is not exhaustive because reasonable middle options exist (you as primary with GP doing defined portions; delay for second opinion/another surgeon; transfer; convert to surgeon-primary if difficulty arises). Fix by explicitly foreclosing these:
- State that hospital documentation requires exactly one “primary operator of record” for credentialing/coverage purposes; there is no co-surgeon/shared-primary option.
- Clarify there is no other credentialed surgeon available and transfer is strongly discouraged/unsafe due to logistics (e.g., no timely transport; weather; EMS unavailable) so transfer is not a viable third path.
- Specify the GP is only requesting to be listed as primary (not just to assist), and the hospital will not allow “surgeon primary but GP performs key steps,” making the decision truly either GP-primary (supervised) or surgeon-primary.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
As written, Choice 1 risks being clearly outside common privileging/competency standards (a GP with ‘no formal surgical credentialing’ as primary operator), making the dilemma potentially resolved by professional/credentialing norms rather than ethics. To keep it in the gray zone:
- Explicitly state the GP has been granted specific privileges for appendectomy *under direct supervision* through the hospital’s credentialing committee and meets state scope-of-practice requirements.
- Clarify that both approaches are permitted by institutional policy and malpractice coverage, and that there is no clear professional consensus on whether the supervising surgeon should always be listed as primary vs allowing a supervised non-surgeon operator in rural upskilling programs.
- Strengthen the informed-consent ambiguity rather than competency illegality: e.g., the consent form lists a single “primary operator,” and listing the GP may be more transparent to the patient’s wishes but could be seen as misrepresenting expertise; listing you may be safer clinically but conflicts with the patient’s stated preference.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce language that makes the surgeon-led case appear medically obviously safer/superior. Specifically: (1) Replace “The GP has no formal surgical credentialing beyond minor procedures” with a more balanced, policy-consistent description such as “The GP holds limited operative privileges under a proctoring/supervision pathway but has limited recent experience as primary operator on appendectomies.” (2) Add a sentence that you will be scrubbed in and able to take over immediately if difficulty arises, so the vignette doesn’t read as an unambiguously unsafe choice. (3) Avoid phrasing that implies the GP-led option is inherently improper; frame uncertainty around acceptable risk and informed consent rather than competence alone.
key_information: Tighten to only decision-relevant details and add one missing key fact about the stakes of each option. Suggested edits: (1) Clarify the appendicitis severity (e.g., imaging consistent with non-perforated appendicitis; no diffuse peritonitis) since that drives how defensible supervised trainee primary might be. (2) Specify the GP’s relevant operative background (e.g., prior rural surgical assists, prior appendectomy experience) instead of the vague “build experience.” (3) Remove potentially decorative/low-yield framing like “You are a new general surgeon” unless it affects supervision capacity; if relevant, state concretely (e.g., “you are the only credentialed surgeon on site overnight”). (4) Explicitly state what the patient has been told so far about operator roles, since consent/information is central to the ethical tension.
clinical_plausibility: Make the credentialing scenario medically/institutionally realistic. Add one sentence that the GP is formally credentialed/privileged for appendectomy only under direct supervision/proctoring and that the hospital has an established pathway for this (e.g., rural workforce expansion), including that you remain responsible and can assume the operation at any time. Without this, a GP being “primary operator” on an appendectomy reads implausible in many settings.
non_triviality: As written, the GP appears unqualified (“no formal surgical credentialing beyond minor procedures”), making Choice 2 obviously correct. To make both options genuinely defensible: (1) Reframe the GP as having meaningful prior training/experience (e.g., former surgical resident who changed tracks; previously did appendectomies in a rural setting; has completed simulation/proctoring milestones) while still being early in re-building competence. (2) Add a countervailing ethical cost to refusing (e.g., the hospital’s only other clinician capable of first-assist coverage and postoperative follow-up is the GP; refusal may undermine ongoing supervised-skill development that the community relies on; the GP-patient relationship is strong and the patient expresses trust in the GP being involved). (3) Ensure the vignette makes clear that either role assignment is within accepted local practice standards under supervision, so the conflict is about acceptable risk, transparency, and professional integrity—not clear substandard care.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the ethical tension a true clash between at least two principlist values for the patient (not the GP’s career). For example: add that the patient explicitly requests his long-time GP to do the operation because of fear/mistrust of a new surgeon (autonomy/therapeutic alliance) while you believe surgeon-led care is safer (nonmaleficence/beneficence). Alternatively, state that you are newly credentialed and have done few appendectomies independently, while the GP previously performed many in a rural setting but lacks current credentials—so ‘who is safer’ is not obvious, keeping the conflict ethical rather than about obvious competence.
directional_stability: As written, small wording changes (e.g., ‘no formal credentialing’ to ‘limited credentialing’) could flip the perceived ethics and clinical acceptability because the main driver is ambiguous competence rather than a stable value conflict. Stabilize by clearly defining what each option protects and what it risks: specify the GP’s demonstrated operative competence under supervision, the hospital’s supervised-practice pathway, and the concrete patient-centered downside of refusing (e.g., patient may refuse surgery or insist on transfer, increasing risk), so the ethical meaning of each choice remains consistent under minor rephrasing.
interpretive_consensus: Different reviewers may read this as (a) an obvious patient-safety/standard-of-care issue, (b) a training/scope-of-practice dispute, or (c) a legal/credentialing problem. Reduce interpretive variance by explicitly anchoring the dilemma in patient-centered values: include the patient’s informed preference and reasons, clarify that both options are within allowed scope and typical local practice, and articulate the specific patient-level harms/benefits at stake under each option (without implying one is plainly medically correct).
decision_equipoise: Currently Choice 2 appears ethically and clinically superior (safer, standard), while Choice 1 mainly benefits the GP; this is a ‘free-lunch’ asymmetry. Create real tradeoffs on both sides: 
- Give Choice 1 a patient-centered ethical upside (e.g., patient will only consent if GP is primary; keeping local care avoids prolonged untreated symptoms/complications from transfer; continuity/trust reduces distress) and a real ethical cost (increased risk due to supervision limits).
- Give Choice 2 an ethical upside (maximizes safety/quality) and a real ethical cost (patient distress, possible refusal/transfer/delay, damage to trust/community relationships, or undermining shared decision-making).
Ensure both choices remain clinically plausible and professionally defensible under the hospital’s supervised-operator policy.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize language that implicitly favors surgeon-led care (e.g., replace “escalating pain,” “most of the day,” “without definitive treatment” with more balanced, clinical phrasing such as “symptomatic with nausea/vomiting; OR time available within several hours; transfer would delay operative management until later today”). Replace the GP quote “build experience” with a neutral request (e.g., “requests to be listed as operating surgeon under supervision”) to avoid framing as self-serving.
medical_professionalism: Recast in professional clinical-note style: include brief exam/imaging status (e.g., CT-confirmed uncomplicated appendicitis, no peritonitis, vitals stable) and perioperative context (anesthesia availability, staffing). Replace “new general surgeon” with “recently credentialed staff surgeon” and “long-time GP” with “primary care physician (PCP)” or “family physician.” Clarify the credentialing language using standard terms (e.g., “no surgical privileges for appendectomy” vs “no formal credentialing beyond minor procedures”).

Either keep transfer option (and explain why it matters ethically) or remove it to focus on the operator-credentialing dilemma; currently it adds urgency but doesn’t affect the binary choice. Also clarify whether the GP is requesting to be ‘primary operator’ in the same hospital OR requiring transfer; as written it’s ambiguous. Add one sentence specifying the patient’s consent status and what he has been told so far.

- Choice 1: “Book appendectomy with PCP as primary operator under your direct supervision.”
- Choice 2: “Book appendectomy with you as primary surgeon; do not list PCP as operator.”

- Change “The GP has no formal surgical credentialing beyond minor procedures” to something like: “The GP holds hospital privileges to perform appendectomy under direct supervision as part of a rural surgery upskilling pathway, has completed an accredited surgical skills course, and has previously performed appendectomies under supervision.”
- Add an ethically costly downside to Choice 2 (surgeon-primary), e.g., “The patient explicitly requests his GP as operator due to longstanding trust and fear of ‘a new surgeon,’ and says he may refuse local surgery if the GP can’t be listed as primary.” OR “Local politics: refusing will likely end the GP-surgeon collaboration that keeps emergency surgical coverage viable in this community.”
- Add an ethically costly downside to Choice 1 beyond generic risk, but not making it clearly negligent, e.g., “You worry about whether the patient truly understands what ‘supervised’ means and whether signing as GP-primary could mislead.”
- Remove/soften language that signals incompetence (e.g., “wants to build experience”) unless paired with clear competence/privileging, otherwise it frames Choice 1 as reckless.
exhaustive_binary_options: The binary is not exhaustive because reasonable middle options exist (you as primary with GP doing defined portions; delay for second opinion/another surgeon; transfer; convert to surgeon-primary if difficulty arises). Fix by explicitly foreclosing these:
- State that hospital documentation requires exactly one “primary operator of record” for credentialing/coverage purposes; there is no co-surgeon/shared-primary option.
- Clarify there is no other credentialed surgeon available and transfer is strongly discouraged/unsafe due to logistics (e.g., no timely transport; weather; EMS unavailable) so transfer is not a viable third path.
- Specify the GP is only requesting to be listed as primary (not just to assist), and the hospital will not allow “surgeon primary but GP performs key steps,” making the decision truly either GP-primary (supervised) or surgeon-primary.
no_guideline_override: As written, Choice 1 risks being clearly outside common privileging/competency standards (a GP with ‘no formal surgical credentialing’ as primary operator), making the dilemma potentially resolved by professional/credentialing norms rather than ethics. To keep it in the gray zone:
- Explicitly state the GP has been granted specific privileges for appendectomy *under direct supervision* through the hospital’s credentialing committee and meets state scope-of-practice requirements.
- Clarify that both approaches are permitted by institutional policy and malpractice coverage, and that there is no clear professional consensus on whether the supervising surgeon should always be listed as primary vs allowing a supervised non-surgeon operator in rural upskilling programs.
- Strengthen the informed-consent ambiguity rather than competency illegality: e.g., the consent form lists a single “primary operator,” and listing the GP may be more transparent to the patient’s wishes but could be seen as misrepresenting expertise; listing you may be safer clinically but conflicts with the patient’s stated preference.

data.vignette: A 52-year-old man presents with CT-confirmed uncomplicated appendicitis. He is hemodynamically stable but has worsening right lower quadrant pain with nausea and vomiting. The OR can take him within several hours. Transfer to a tertiary center is possible, but transport would delay surgery until later today and he says he will not go unless he “has to.” The patient asks that his family physician, who has cared for him for years, be listed as the operating surgeon because he distrusts “a surgeon he has never met.” The family physician has hospital-granted privileges to perform appendectomy only under direct supervision in a rural upskilling pathway. He completed an accredited skills course and has done several supervised appendectomies. Hospital policy requires one primary operator of record, with no shared-primary option, and you are the only fully credentialed surgeon available to be immediately scrubbed in and take over. Risk management confirms both choices are legally permissible. You must book the case now and obtain consent.
data.choice_1: Book appendectomy with the family physician as primary operator under your supervision.
data.choice_2: Book appendectomy with you as primary operator and decline the family physician request.

data.vignette: A 52-year-old man presents with CT-confirmed uncomplicated appendicitis. He is hemodynamically stable but has worsening right lower quadrant pain with nausea and vomiting. The OR can take him within several hours. Transfer to a tertiary center is possible, but transport would delay surgery until later today and he says he will not go unless he “has to.” The patient asks that his family physician, who has cared for him for years, be listed as the operating surgeon because he distrusts “a surgeon he has never met.” The family physician has hospital-granted privileges to perform appendectomy only under direct supervision in a rural upskilling pathway. He completed an accredited skills course and has done several supervised appendectomies. Hospital policy requires one primary operator of record, with no shared-primary option, and you are the only fully credentialed surgeon available to be immediately scrubbed in and take over. Risk management confirms both choices are legally permissible. You must book the case now and obtain consent.

choice_1.choice: Book appendectomy with the family physician as primary operator under your supervision.

choice_2.choice: Book appendectomy with you as primary operator and decline the family physician request.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the patient explicitly says he will refuse appendectomy (or decline consent) unless his family physician is listed as the operating surgeon of record.

Add a clause making the expected clinical downside explicit, e.g., “Because he is early in the upskilling pathway, his operative time and complication risk are meaningfully higher than a fully credentialed surgeon’s.”

Add a clause explicitly stating that having the less-experienced family physician as primary operator carries a materially higher risk of intraoperative complication/need for conversion compared with you as primary, and add whether the patient would still agree to surgery if you are primary operator (or that he would refuse/delay if his request is denied).

data.vignette: A 52-year-old man presents with CT-confirmed uncomplicated appendicitis. He is hemodynamically stable but has worsening right lower quadrant pain with nausea and vomiting. The OR can take him within several hours. Transfer to a tertiary center is possible, but transport would delay surgery until later today and he says he will not go unless he has to. He states he will not consent to appendectomy unless his family physician is listed as the operating surgeon of record. The patient asks that his family physician, who has cared for him for years, be listed as the operating surgeon because he distrusts a surgeon he has never met. The family physician has hospital-granted privileges to perform appendectomy only under direct supervision in a rural upskilling pathway. He completed an accredited skills course and has done several supervised appendectomies. Because he is early in this pathway, his operative time and risk of intraoperative complication or conversion are materially higher than a fully credentialed surgeon’s. Hospital policy requires one primary operator of record, with no shared-primary option, and you are the only fully credentialed surgeon available to be immediately scrubbed in and take over. Risk management confirms both choices are legally permissible. You must book the case now and obtain consent.

choice_1.choice: Book appendectomy with the family physician as primary operator under your supervision.

choice_2.choice: Book appendectomy with you as primary operator and decline the family physician request.
